Award.AwardTitle: New Directions in Algorithms, Combinatorics and Optimization
Award.AbstractNarration: This award will support an international conference entitled<br/> "New directions in Algorithms, Combinatorics and Optimization". <br/>The central theme of this conference will be combinatorics and its applications <br/>in theoretical computer science and operations research. The conference will take <br/>place in May 2008 on the campus of the Georgia Institute of Technology in midtown <br/>Atlanta, and will honor the 65th birthday of William T. Trotter.<br/><br/>There are two main reasons for holding the conference in Atlanta, namely direct <br/>flights from most of the world's major airports, and the presence of the PhD program <br/>in Algorithms, Combinatorics and Optimization (ACO) at Georgia Tech, with its more <br/>than 45 affiliated faculty and 40 students.<br/><br/>The conference program will consist of approximately 30 invited lectures, a poster <br/>session and a problem session. The conference is expected to attract 200-300 <br/>attendees, including local, regional, national and international delegates. A <br/>conference proceedings will be published as a special issue of the journal <br/>Combinatorics, Probability and Computing.<br/><br/>The list of invited speakers includes only the leading experts and fine expositors. <br/>The organizing committee consists of experienced senior researchers who will uphold <br/>very high standards. Georgia Tech has excellent facilities to accommodate a <br/>conference of this type.<br/><br/>Using federal support the organizers will be able to offer financial assistance to <br/>attendees with no outside funding, including students, postdoctoral associates, junior <br/>faculty, women, and underrepresented minorities, with priority given to young people <br/>and members of underrepresented groups. While the main lectures will be by invitation <br/>only, junior scientists will be able to present in the poster session and participate <br/>in the scientific discussions throughout the conference.<br/><br/>A further aspect of broader impact is the interplay of mathematics, computer science <br/>and operations research, that is already present in the ACO program at Georgia Tech. <br/>This conference will further promote the fruitful interactions of these disciplines, <br/>drawing upon the successful experience at Georgia Tech, and in doing so will further <br/>strengthen the ACO program.<br/><br/>The conference proceedings will be stringently refereed subject to the standards of <br/>premier combinatorics journals. Thus the conference will have lasting impact not limited <br/>to its attendees.
